docs.title: MyBible CLI Java
docs.text:
Welcome to the documentation for MyBible CLI Java — a fast, cross-platform command-line and GUI tool for accessing biblical text from MyBible modules.

  • Command-Line Interface

    Fast verse fetching, flexible output formatting, and easy integration with other tools.

    CLI Documentation

  • Graphical Interface

    Simple, themeable GUI with customizable text display and keyboard shortcuts.

    GUI Documentation

  • Get Started

    Download pre-built applications or build from source.

    Installation Guide

  • Examples

    Practical examples and recipes for common use cases.

    View Examples

docs.title: About This Project
docs.text: MyBible CLI Java is inspired by diatheke, the standard command-line tool for Crosswire Sword modules. While diatheke is powerful, it works only with Crosswire Sword modules and does not support the MyBible format, which has an extensive library of high-quality modules.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Fast Verse Retrieval: Quickly fetch and display verses from any MyBible module
  • Flexible Formatting: Control output with customizable format strings
  • Book Name Mappings: Use default abbreviations or create custom mappings
  • Dual Interface: Use via command-line for scripting or GUI for interactive lookups
  • Cross-Platform: Works on Windows, macOS, and Linux

docs.title: Purpose
docs.text:
This tool is designed as a quick lookup tool for biblical text, not a comprehensive Bible study application. It excels at:

  • Fast text retrieval for use in other applications
  • Scriptable access to biblical text
  • Integration into automated workflows
  • Quick reference lookups

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Download Pre-builtBuild from Source

Download the latest version from the Releases page.

Platform-specific applications include Java runtime — no separate Java installation required.

# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/kosivantsov/mybible-cli-java.git
cd mybible-cli-java

# Build JAR
./gradlew clean shadowJar

# Run
java -jar build/libs/mybible-cli.jar

You'll Need MyBible Modules

To use this application, you need at least one MyBible module (.sqlite3 file). See MyBible Modules for download sources.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: This page provides detailed installation instructions for MyBible CLI Java on different platforms.

docs.title: For Pre-built Applications
docs.text: Pre-built applications include the required Java runtime and have no external dependencies.

docs.title: For Running JAR Files
docs.text:
• Java Runtime: JDK or JRE 17 or higher
  • MyBible Modules: At least one .sqlite3 module file

Check your Java version:

java -version

docs.title: Installation Methods
docs.text: WindowsmacOSLinux

docs.title: Pre-built Application
docs.text:
1. Download the installer from Releases:

    • mybible-cli-windows-gui.msi - GUI only, no terminal window
    • mybible-cli-windows-cli-gui.msi - Both CLI and GUI (terminal opens with GUI)

  2. Run the installer

  3. Choose installation location
  4. Application will be added to Start Menu

docs.title: Using the CLI (cli-gui version)
docs.text:
# From Command Prompt
mybible-cli get -r "John 3:16"

docs.title: JAR File
docs.text:
1. Download mybible-cli.jar from Releases
  2. Run: java -jar mybible-cli.jar

docs.title: Pre-built Application
docs.text:
1. Download mybible-cli-macos.dmg from Releases
  2. Open the DMG file
  3. Drag application to Applications folder
  4. Right-click and select "Open" first time (security requirement)

docs.title: Command Line Usage
docs.text:
# Add to PATH (optional)
sudo ln -s /Applications/MyBible-CLI.app/Contents/MacOS/MyBible-CLI /usr/local/bin/mybible-cli

# Now you can run from terminal
mybible-cli get -r "John 3:16"

docs.title: Getting MyBible Modules
docs.text:
After installation, you need to download MyBible modules:

  1. Download modules from ph4.org or other sources
  2. Unzip the downloaded files (.zip → .sqlite3)
  3. Store in a dedicated folder (e.g., ~/MyBible/modules/)
  4. Set path using: 
    mybible-cli list --path "/path/to/your/modules"

See MyBible Modules for detailed information about available modules and sources.

docs.title: Verification
docs.text:
Test your installation:

CLIGUI 
# Check help
mybible-cli help

# Set module path (first time)
mybible-cli list --path "/path/to/modules"

# List available modules
mybible-cli list

# Fetch a verse
mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "John 3:16"

# Launch GUI
mybible-cli gui
  1. Click "Set Module Path" if prompted
  2. Select your modules folder
  3. Choose a module from dropdown
  4. Enter a reference (e.g., "John 3:16")
  5. Click "Get Verses"

docs.title: "Command not found" (Linux/macOS)
docs.text:
# Check if installed
which mybible-cli

# If using JAR, create alias
alias mybible-cli='java -jar /path/to/mybible-cli.jar'

# Make permanent (add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc)
echo "alias mybible-cli='java -jar /path/to/mybible-cli.jar'" >> ~/.bashrc

docs.title: Java Version Issues
docs.text:
# Check Java version
java -version

# Should be 17 or higher
# If not, install newer Java:

# Ubuntu/Debian
sudo apt install openjdk-17-jre

# macOS (using Homebrew)
brew install openjdk@17

# Fedora
sudo dnf install java-17-openjdk

docs.title: macOS Security Warning
docs.text:
If you see "cannot be opened because it is from an unidentified developer":

  1. Right-click the application
  2. Select "Open"
  3. Click "Open" in the security dialog

docs.title: MyBible Modules
docs.text: This page explains what MyBible modules are, where to get them, and how to manage them.

docs.title: What are MyBible Modules?
docs.text:
MyBible modules are SQLite database files (.sqlite3 extension) containing biblical text. They follow the MyBible format specification and include:

  • Biblical text in various translations
  • Book names and metadata
  • Optional features:
    • Strong's numbers
    • Morphological data
    • Cross-references
    • Footnotes

docs.title: Primary Source: ph4.org
docs.text:
The main repository for MyBible modules is ph4.org

Browse available Bibles, commentaries, and other resources.

docs.title: Other Sources
docs.text:
• MyBible official website (for mobile app modules)
  • Community contributions
  • Self-created modules (if you have the tools)

docs.title: Step 1: Download
docs.text:
1. Visit ph4.org
  2. Browse or search for desired translation
  3. Download the .zip file

docs.title: Step 2: Extract
docs.text:
Unzip the downloaded file to get the .sqlite3 file:

# Linux/macOS
unzip KJV.zip

# Windows - use built-in or 7-Zip

docs.title: Step 3: Organize
docs.text:
Create a dedicated folder for your modules:

# Recommended structure
MyBible/
└── modules/
    ├── KJV.sqlite3
    ├── NET.sqlite3
    ├── ESV.sqlite3
    └── ...

docs.title: Step 4: Configure
docs.text:
Tell mybible-cli where your modules are:

mybible-cli list --path "/path/to/MyBible/modules"

docs.title: List All Modules
docs.text:
mybible-cli list

Output: 

Module path: /home/user/MyBible/modules

Available modules:
  ESV - English Standard Version
  KJV - King James Version
  NET - New English Translation
  NASB - New American Standard Bible

Total: 4 modules

docs.title: Check Module Details
docs.text:
mybible-cli get -m NET -r "John 3:16" --json

Inspect the JSON output to see: - Module name - Available features (Strong's, morphology, etc.) - Text format

docs.title: Module Information
docs.text:
Use the parse command to test a module:

mybible-cli parse -r "John 3:16"

docs.title: English Translations
docs.text: Module Description Features KJV King James Version (1611) Classic, poetic language ESV English Standard Version Literal, modern NET New English Translation Extensive notes, free NASB New American Standard Very literal NIV New International Version Thought-for-thought

docs.title: Other Languages
docs.text:
MyBible format supports hundreds of translations in various languages:

  • Spanish: RVR1960, BTX
  • German: Luther1912, Schlachter
  • Russian: RUSV, RST
  • French: LSG, BDS
  • Portuguese: ACF, ARA
  • And many more...

docs.title: Strong's Numbers
docs.text:
Some modules include Strong's concordance numbers:

mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "John 1:1" -f "%X"

Output shows Strong's numbers like <S>G3056</S> (logos).

docs.title: Formatting Tags
docs.text:
Modules may include:

  • <pb /> - Paragraph breaks
  • <t>text</t> - Title/heading
  • <J>text</J> - Words of Jesus (red letter)
  • <i>text</i> - Italics
  • <n>text</n> - Footnote
  • <S>G1234</S> - Strong's number

Use format specifiers to control how these are rendered:

  • %T - Raw text with all tags
  • %t - Clean multi-line text
  • %X - Formatted with Strong's
  • %Y - Formatted without Strong's
  • %Z - Single-line formatted

See Output Formatting for details.

docs.title: Supported
docs.text:
• ✅ Bible text modules (.SQLite3)
  • ✅ All MyBible-compatible translations
  • ✅ Modules with Strong's numbers
  • ✅ Modules with morphological data

docs.title: Not Currently Supported
docs.text:
• ❌ Commentary modules
  • ❌ Dictionary modules
  • ❌ Devotional modules
  • ❌ Non-Bible content

Note

This tool is designed specifically for Bible text retrieval. Other MyBible module types are not supported.

docs.title: Creating Custom Book Name Mappings
docs.text:
If you need custom abbreviations (e.g., for different languages):

Create a text file with mappings:

# custom-books.txt
Genesis|Gen|Ge|Gn
Exodus|Exo|Ex
...
John|Jn|Jean|Juan

Use it:

mybible-cli get -r "Jn 3:16" -b custom-books.txt

See Configuration for details.

docs.title: "No modules found"
docs.text:
# Check path is set
mybible-cli list

# Set path if needed
mybible-cli list --path "/correct/path/to/modules"

docs.title: "Module not found: XYZ"
docs.text:
# List available modules
mybible-cli list

# Check spelling and case
mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "John 3:16"  # Case-sensitive

docs.title: Corrupted Module
docs.text:
If a module appears corrupted:

  1. Re-download from source
  2. Verify it's unzipped correctly
  3. Check file extension is .sqlite3

docs.title: Module Path Not Persisting
docs.text:
The path is stored in config.json. Location:

  • Windows: %APPDATA%\mybible-cli-java\config.json
  • macOS: ~/Library/Application Support/mybible-cli-java/config.json
  • Linux: ~/.config/mybible-cli-java/config.json

docs.title: Quick Start Guide
docs.text: Get up and running with MyBible CLI Java in minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
1. Install the application - See Installation Guide
  2. Download MyBible modules - See MyBible Modules

docs.title: Step 1: Set Module Path
docs.text:
Tell the application where your MyBible modules are stored:

mybible-cli list --path "/path/to/your/MyBible/modules"

Example paths:

WindowsmacOSLinux 
mybible-cli list --path "C:\Users\YourName\Documents\MyBible\modules"

mybible-cli list --path "$HOME/Documents/MyBible/modules"

mybible-cli list --path "$HOME/MyBible/modules"

docs.title: Step 2: List Available Modules
docs.text:
mybible-cli list

You should see your installed modules:

Available modules:
  - KJV (King James Version)
  - NET (New English Translation)
  - ESV (English Standard Version)

docs.title: Fetch a Single Verse
docs.text:
mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "John 3:16"

Output: 

For God so loved the world, that he gave his only begotten Son...

docs.title: Fetch Multiple Verses
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "Romans 8:28-30"

docs.title: Fetch Multiple Passages
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m NET -r "John 3:16; Romans 8:28; Ephesians 2:8-10"

docs.title: Use Last Module
docs.text:
# After first use, you can omit -m
mybible-cli get -r "Psalm 23"

docs.title: GUI Mode
docs.text:
Launch the GUI:

mybible-cli gui

Or with a pre-loaded passage:

mybible-cli gui -m KJV -r "John 3:16"

In the GUI:

  1. Select module from dropdown
  2. Enter reference (e.g., "John 3:16")
  3. Press Enter or click "Get Verses"
  4. Use Ctrl+L / Cmd+L to focus reference field
  5. Use Ctrl+M / Cmd+M to focus module dropdown

docs.title: Read a Chapter
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "Psalm 23"

docs.title: Read Multiple Chapters
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "Matthew 5-7"

docs.title: Custom Output Format
docs.text:
# Show verse numbers before text
mybible-cli get -m NET -r "Romans 8:28-30" -f "%v. %t"

Output: 

28. And we know that...
29. For those whom he foreknew...
30. And those whom he predestined...

docs.title: Copy Output to Clipboard
docs.text:
LinuxmacOSWindows 
mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "John 3:16" | xclip -selection clipboard

mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "Psalm 23" | pbcopy

mybible-cli get -m NET -r "Romans 8:28" | clip

docs.title: Save to File
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "Psalm 119" > psalm119.txt

docs.title: Get JSON Output
docs.text:
mybible-cli get -m NET -r "John 3:16" --json

{
  "module": "NET",
  "verses": [
    {
      "book": 500,
      "chapter": 3,
      "verse": 16,
      "text": "For this is the way God loved the world..."
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Keyboard Shortcuts (GUI)
docs.text: Shortcut Action Esc Quit application Ctrl+L / Cmd+L Focus reference input Ctrl+M / Cmd+M Focus module dropdown Ctrl+J / Cmd+J Toggle JSON view Ctrl+Shift+C / Cmd+Shift+C Copy formatted text Cmd+, (macOS) Open settings

docs.title: Create Shell Alias
docs.text:
Add to your ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc:

alias bible='mybible-cli get'

Now you can use:

bible -r "John 3:16"

docs.title: Daily Verse Script
docs.text:
#!/bin/bash
# daily-verse.sh
DAY=$(date +%d)
mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "Proverbs $DAY"

docs.title: Search Within Output
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m KJV -r "John 1" | grep -i "word"

docs.title: Count Words in Passage
docs.text: mybible-cli get -m ESV -r "Genesis 1" -f "%z" | wc -w
